reviewText:
I have only played a very tiny portion of the game, but i can tell this'll be an awesome experience.

Things similar to original game:
-Evil robots wanting to kill you
-Ability to look at cameras
-Helplessness in a single office chair
-Lights to help you see in the darkness

Things DIFFERENT to the original game
-New robots, along with the old robots (Not sure how many exactly, heard anything from 8-11 of them)
- No doors
-Unable to run out of power (Flashlight is able to run out of power)
-Flashlight to see in dark corners of rooms.
-More rooms
-New sounds
-Added mechanics.

So far, i LOVE the game, and i can't wait to beat the first night. Ok, MAYBE i panicked, but don't judge meh :3
voteText: 656 of 790 people (83%) found this review helpful 35 people found this review funny

reviewText:
This game is very educational and teaches kids many things. The story is well thought out, and you must use your mind to conquer the game.

You play as a man named Jeremy, who is a Jedi and can wind up things in other rooms. He must wind up a music box to keep his very skinny son from running down the hall and giving him a big kiss, because you know, he loves him and stuff. You must also watch out for other animatronics, because they tend to wander around the restaurant to find someone to play chess with. The old animatronics in the supply closet are too socially awkward and wander around to find a friend, too. If they end up in your office, you must put a mask on to remind them of their grandpa ol' fredbear and teach them discipline. I guess Jeremy hates chess, so he must defend himself from getting distracted and getting $100.50. Now, foxy is a big dancer. So to make him go away, you must flash strobe lights in his face and give him a seizure while you try to use the force on the music box. Eventually, the animatronics will survey the vents for critters blocking them. Also, balloon boy is a big problem you must worry about. He graduated at the finest school of engineering, and if he gets in your office, he will disable your lights and flashlight :(

I give this game a 8/8. Great job Scott!

reviewText:
PROS:
- fun gameplay
- spooky ambience
- easy-to-learn manuevers
- the win screen is so refreshing
CONS:
- death gets annoying
- night 6 is extremely difficult
- strictly based on audio cues, so you're punished for turning down/off the sound

Final rating: 8.5/10

reviewText:
EDIT: Fun game. Terrifying and fast paced in the later nights. If you don't have good reaction times, you won't make it through night 5-6. as of right now, I have only beaten night 5. I won't reveal much but the balloon boy is probably the /most/ annoying AI as it is pure luck in night 6 that he won't come in and screw things up for your night. the new golden freddy (yes, he is indeed back) has 2 ways to get you. and both are equally frightening. I've never been more afraid to see a floating bear head in my life.

New AI: 9/10 - annoying, but Hella hard to outsmart.
Storyline: 8/10 -- albeit short, there is not really much needed to be said. seems like scott is trying to drag us along slowly into a very deep, dark hole we call the story of five nights at freddy's".
Replayability:5/10 -- this really depends on your interests
date:
IMHO. this is more of a "one and you're done" kinda game.
secrets and extras: 8/10 -- I've seen a lot of little things if you have time to pay attention and explore. the  custom night is great as well.

all in all

reviewText: This game is an incredible stress reliever. It provides a very pleasant and peaceful experience and reminds me of chilling in the beach and listening to the waves. It will calm your nerves and switch your personality from type A to B. The relaxation level you derive from it is almost as good as being tipsy. Everyone should play it when they are in the mood for anxiety calming!!

reviewText: Took what the first game gave it and in 3 months, made of the most successful horror titles of 2014. I'd reccomend buying this one instead of FNAF, FNAF 3 and/or FNAF 4. This one is by far the most difficult but it also has the most content. if you are looking for a challenging horror game with a decent backstory, Go ahead and buy FNAF 2.

reviewText:
WARNING: This game is not for the soft hearted. It's terrifying with the sounds off.
Gameplay: This game produces a wonderously stressful experience wich will keep you at the edge of your seat at all moments. 9/10
Graphics: The game's appearance changed very little, and still look grainy. I honestly don't even think this game has any lighting system. 6/10
Scare factor: That wonderous feeling you get when your freind jumps out of you the five hundredth time-- is stale... Experienced players will find this more of a challenge than a horror game, but new players will get a kick out of it. 7/10
Originality: I honestly have never seen a game like this. Besides the first Five Nights at Freddy's of course. 10/10
Performance: This game could probably run on a Game Boy  (not literally) 10/10
Total score: 88% This game is a great experience for the brave ones, but lacks in graphical quality.

reviewText: Definitely not the same feeling as jumping into your office chair for the first time, not knowing what is going on and then losing all power before 5am. Despite this it is still an excellent game. Scott made the right decision by altering gameplay and removing the doors; Five Nights at Freddy's began to see many uprising strategies to easily beat the game without much to worry about, but with 11 animatronics running around, attacking from 3 directions this time, strategies have become almost useless. Five Nights at Freddy's 2 began much differently than it's predecessor. I was there, with many others, the minute it was released on steam, but the first Five Nights at Freddy's only began to see popularity after youtube playthroughs such as Markiplier's. Although I cannot get past night 4, this is a great game, I have had a lot of fun in the short time I have played and I plan to have a lot more. I rate this game 20/20/20/20/20/20/20/20/20/20! But in all seriousness,  10/10!

reviewText: I would recomend this game if you liked and played the first one.\nIf you didn't play the first one, don't get this one yet. You'll miss some story"
date: and this second one is significantly more complex and fantastically frustrating than the first.\n\nThere are some pros and cons to this new game that I should address
recommended:
though.

Pros:
More killer robots
A better "Chuck E Cheese" feel
New audio cues
Perplexing 'story' elements
M. Scott ShamaCawthon
Mildly spookier death scream
Interesting game mechanics

Cons:
Music Box ruins the gameplay

reviewText:
The following preparations are required before playing this game. In order to have a scary and terrifying adventure.

--- Night time
--- comfortable rotating chair
--- Home alone
--- Headphones on a loud enough volume for you to hear every single creepy sound
--- Full screen
--- Now I haven't actually tried this myself because well I know I wouldn't be able to cope (I am a puss* I know) BUT... To really play like a pro, play this game in a room filled with clowns, dolls, etc. Trust me... That would be some scary shi*.
--- And if you want it to the Maximum maybe get drunk or get high before playing (I have witnessed this happen :3 )

The following preparations are for those who are too afraid to play it like a pro. ^^

--- Daytime
--- Diapers / Nappies
--- With a group of people
--- Speakers

I Recommend this game for people who like a LOT of thrill, I do not however recommend it for old people, trust me... I know from experience with my Grandparents... (I didn't let them play it fyi)

Good luck! Just trying to help :)
( Oh and first time I played this game I played it like a pro, I fell off my comfortable rotating chair, onto the floor and stayed there for about 2 minutes because the first jumpscare was too much for me to handle, I haven't gotten past the 2nd night yet... YET )

reviewText:
Now that i've had some time with this game i'm gonna write a review,
if you live under a rock and don't know wat FNAF is i'll explain it.
it's basiclly the horrer boom on the internet of the late 2014 period, it's a game where you take a night shift at a chuck E cheese like pizzeria. the animatronics though work at night and want nothing more than you in a robotic exoskelaton, so you know, gotta stay away from them hey, but how?
Well the game used a unique system which required some stratigic skill and planning, you can't actully move and you don't have a weapon, instead you look at security cameras scattered throughout the facility. When an animatronic is outside your door you need to close it, but at the expense of your oh so precious power.
This game is scary because of it's atmoshere and the inability to move or fight and because of the silence in the backround with weird noises playing with it. It's mysterious and strange story filled with mythos was also highly welcomed.
This game made a massive boom of popularity across the internet [ specificcly youtube ] with let's plays and reaction videos everywhere.

about a season later in the year we're already back at freddy fazbears pizzeria, but are you getting a warm childrens tune or a fox [ or a puppet ] lunging at us instead? We have unlimited power in this sequel but I still say  it's a harder game, how? Well first of all there are no doors, instead there are 2 vents next to you and a massive passage to a hallway in front of you. Also there are 6 new animatronics, 5 of which want you dead snd the other will make you vulnerble to the rest. So how do escape from their terrible grasp.
You have a mask.
This mask will fool most of them into thinking your one of them and will keep them at bay, but as I said there are other animatronics that you need to keep away [ conveniently the most dangerous ones ] and their own ways of being tricked seems like a hard chore. Sometimes you'll be caught in a situation where you'll never make it out alive.

This game is way harder than the original and will rquire more of your freddy fazbear skills. Overall though you should be more entertained by the mysterious story [ and substory ] and setting that ulimately fuels the game.

7.9
really good                                                                  PROS:
- mysterious and cool story with a great horrer setting
- new gameplay mechanics are good....
CONS
- ....but some are a chore
- really, really hard

reviewText:
Wow. What could I say about this game? Well, i'll add a pro's and con's list.
WARNING: SPOILER ALERTS.

Pros:
Very fun
Keeps you on edge the whole time
You will get scared, even if you feel brave after the 1000 attempt.
Up to 7 nights. Nights 1-5, night 6 and custom night (Night 7)
Great story line
Lots of easter eggs
Lots of enemies
Lots of jumpscares!
Small minigames
Small cutscenes
Great atmosphere
Cons:
Game can become more annoying then scary when trying to complete night 5, 6 and certain game modes in night 7 (Such as 10/20 or 4/20)
No pause menu(This isn't a problem for me but if you ever need to stop playing to take a break you can't.)
Dull endings (Night 5 is a check, night 6 is a bonus check and a newspaper saying the place is closing and night 7 is you getting fired. No cutscene for any endings)
Too fast. You will be looking left and right while flashing foxy while winding up the box while putting the mask to hide from bonnie and repeat. One slight mistake and it's back to 12 AM.

epilogue:


Overall the game is a fun game to play, you will be scared, you will be astounished by the story behind it and more. The game does get a bit hard towards the end, espically when you get those bonus nights. However, the game is a fun sight to play and even watch youtubers play it. I do recommend this game.

Overall rating : 8.6/10
+Fun
+Scary
+Exciting
+Triller
-------
-Rage simulator
-dull endings.

reviewText:
Hello, hello? Uh, well, if you're hearing this, then chances are... you've made a very poor career choice.

Ready for Freddy? Again? Five Nights at Freddy's 2, the sequel to the highly praised Five Nights at Freddy's, brings a lot of new stuff to the jump scare filled table. With more animatronics to fend off and zero doors to use, Five Night's at Freddy's 2 knows how to make your horror game horribly hard. Compared to its predecessor, Five Nights at Freddy's 2 has a lot more tricks up its sleeve, with random death mini-games and a ton of easter eggs. But the question still remains, is Five Nights at Freddy's 2 still as scary as it was before?

Gameplay Five Nights at Freddy's 2 brings some new gameplay mechanics, as stated above, there are no doors and there is no power generator that can run out. You now depend on a flashlight and a Freddy Fazbear mask. The flashlight is your new power generator in this game. Once you're out of batteries, Foxy will be more than happy to munch your face off. You'll also need this flashlight to shine into the hallway outside your office, and lighten dark corners on the camera feed. The Freddy Fazbear mask is very interesting and works a lot like the old doors. Once an animatronic is in the air vents or in front of you, you'll need to put on the mask to make them go away. If this is not done fast enough, a load jump scare will scare the bejesus out of you. Next to the load of animatronics you have to deal with, you also have to check on the music box every once in a while. If you won't wind up the music box, The Puppet will take good care of you. All these things combined can make some tense scenes, but also a lot of cheap deaths.

Conclusion Five Nights at Freddy's 2 is a very fun and jump scare filled game. For the story gamers around us, there is a lot of background story to uncover, the forums are full of predictions and theories! But like i said, there are a lot of cheap deaths in the game. Night five and six are mostly based around luck, and make you do the same strategy over and over again. But really, who hasn't heard about Five Nights at Freddy's now? If you're a horror fan who can take a lot of jump scares and fun but sometimes unfair gameplay mechanics? This is your game. But the real question is:
À̷̫̺̖͖̖̺͕̬̟̱̲͖͓͇̟͉̦̟͘͝r̷͘͘͏̙͇͍͓̣͎̮̗ͅé̯̖̪͎̫̗̭͉͓̺̣ͅ ̡̗̜̝͕̮͞ͅy̙͔͎̼̦̪͚̲̝͕͓͜͠ó̸̵̺̳̪̰̙̮̭̝̱̬̖͍͔͝u҉̶͚̤̤̤̬͖̙̭̱̹̩̺́͞ ̶̸̴̡̡̯͈̟̱̜r̵̸̞̯̤̘̙͉̝̖̞̠̪̤͙̜͡ę̵̺̪̹̤̖̫͓̻̼́͟a̡͕̭̪̝̥̬̘͉̝͇̠͕̜̖̖̯͓͘̕͢͠ḑ̧̤͇̥͇͔͉̳̱̙̹̞y̨̨̭̩͔̺̺̦͉̻͚̤̺̤͍̱͘͝ ̸̡̘͖̝͎̯̻̻̹̦̭̖̮̰̤̻f̧͚̲̻̞̝̣̞͔̮̺́͞o̧̨͡͏͈͖̮̱̳͇̲͎͈̪͈͢r̵̝̯͙̪̟̠̩̲̤̖̜̳̲͍̀̕͠ͅ ̴̶̺̫̯͔̟̞̝̭͔͈̮͙̺͎͕̳͞ͅͅF̶̵̨̧̬̼͓̜͓̱̪͙͉̦̞̟̞͔̩̣̳̀ͅŗ̴̨̡̹̣̫̼̫̪̝̤̹͍ę̴҉̸̖͈͔͓̥̻̳͔̦͈͉̺̲͍̰d̸̝̥̠̝̖̠͇̻d̵̡͙̙̪͖y҉̴̸̥̹̞̬̻̣̫̜̪̥̱͍͙͎̖͎̟̹͞?̴̷̡͉̘͓̫̣̮̭͎͔̲̺͓̥͓̳̀

reviewText: Five Nights at Freddy's 2, for something that was developed by a single man in a matter of months, is such a well-constructed game. The strategy element that made the original Five Nights at Freddy's so fun to play has been amped up to the maximum here. The game's use of micro-management keeps the player engaged at all times, perfectly complimenting the ominous soundtrack, audio cues and general atmosphere of the game that presses not only fear upon the player, but a whole lot of stress as well. It's what you'd expect from a good video game: a challenge, and Five Nights at Freddy's 2 is one hell of a challenge.

reviewText:
Five Nights at Freddy's 2 has been a long awaited sequel...well long awaited for me I have been very excited about this!!  Does it live up to its predecessor though, did it do things differently to make the formula seem newer?  Well, yes and no Five Nights at Freddy's 2 is a mixed bag for me but make it well known that I have enjoyed what I have played but there are some things that I do not like about it either and maybe it was because it was rushed out, then again maybe it wasnt and creator Scott Cawthon" was very satisfied with the current build and good on him for that.  But anyway here goes my review of what I have played so far.


I love how Scott decided to change it up a little so that we had the same type of game that we originally loved.  Getting rid of the doors to me was a great idea and added a new type of tension and stress initially starting
date: trying to figure out when to put on the mask and when not to.  Additionally
recommended: the addition of another element that requires you to interact can make things alot more stressful and when put in a bad situation where that element needs attention but you cant do it...ADDS alot of stress to the element and I loved that!  I havent delved into the story yet let alone go out of my way to search for it like we had to with the original but I am hoping Scott added more to this because the way the story was hidden in the last game was fun to read.  Now
hoursPlayed: having said that there are a few things wrong with this game that bug me from the moment I was playing about 10 minutes in...and that was the death animations. reviewText:
Five Nights at Freddy's 2 is a pre-sequel to the original Five Nights at Freddy's.
It takes place in 1987, like last time, you're a security guard in a pizzeria. A haunted pizzeria.
Unlike in the last game, you don't have doors to hide from the Animatronics, instead you get a Freddy Fazbear mask, and a Flashlight. You need to use both of these new gameplay elements, in order to protect from the animatronics. If you see Foxy in the Hallway, you need to flash at him every few seconds, in order to stun him, because the mask doesn't work on him.
When you see any of the new animatronics in the vents' blind spot, you need to put on the mask, and wait until they leave the room.
The storyline explains many mysteries from the first game, such as the missing children accident, in which the 5 kids got kidnapped, and stuffed into the costumes of Bonnie, Chica, Freddy, and Foxy. The phone guy calls you every night, telling you hints and what is currently happening, such as the theft of the Golden Freddy costume (The costume of the kidnapper) and how the animatronics are malfunctioning. When you die, there's a chance you get a Atari minigame, which shows what is happening. In one of these, it tells you to Give Gifts" in which you control Freddy
date: to give gifts to the children
hoursPlayed: it tells you to "Give Life" and you need to... Stuff the kids into the animatronics' suits.\nThe game is a lot harder
voteText: and a lot more scary than the first game. This time you need to look for 10 ANIMATRONICS. In 12 rooms! That's a lot more than in the first game
helpfulPercent: oh I almost did forgot to mention this: There's a music box in the Prize Corner camera
votesHelpful: where you need to wind it up from time to time
votesTotal: otherwise the Marionette will get you.\nThe game has a lot of new mechanics
votesFunny: its a lot more scary
commentsCount: it has a lot of new animatronics
column16: a fitting tension soundtrack when something happens
column17: it's definitely worth the 3 extra dollars.\nIf you liked the first game
column18: get this one definitely. You'll be scared."

reviewText:
The first game in the series was superb. This one takes your original skills and stuffs it into Chica's suit.

This one is much faster paced and MUCH more difficult than the original. It requires extreme reaction timing (tough for lots of people) and lots of awareness. The Marionette, Balloon Boy, and the old animatronics require major skill and bullet speed mouse skills.

Alright, now to even it out with the ol' pros and cons.

PROS:

Very fun overall.
Interesting backstory with a twist.
The new animatronics are quirky and fun.
Has a great difficulty for more experienced gamers.
Somewhat spooky.
The special minigames are to die for (ba-dum-tss), AKA, they're a nice addition.

CONS:

Nowhere near as scary (although the jumpscares are pretty jarring) as the original.
Can be impossible to beat at times.
Rage inducing.
Too fast paced at some times.
You need perfect reaction timing to get past the later nights (3 and on).

Overall, I recommend it, but the first one is slightly better. This one is still very good, though.

reviewText:
FNaF 2 is actually a decent game. Yes the scares are repetitve and predictable, but I found myself actually coming back for more because (unlike the other games in the franchise) this game has a little replayability. The nights are challenging and I found I could play 2+ nights in 1 session without being bored so easily, unlike FNaF 1,3 and 4. The custom night is rather interesting as well because it gives you interesting and difficult challenges that - once complete - will reward you with little plush toy on your desk, which will make you want to collect all of them for a sense of achievement.
Although I don't highly recommend this game, if it's on sale, pick it up. Have a go!

Recommended - 5/10

reviewText:
So I never played the original internet takeover, that the original Five nights at Freddy's was. Mainly because I'd watched so many playthroughs on it, that I went from being scared with the youtuber to laughing at how adorably lacking they are at knowing the strategies. Since this only just come out, I decided to give it a go myself, completely unaware of how many times I would want to shove Foxy's face inside a blender.

Here's the main question you probably want an answer for. Is it good? Absolutely. Is it scary? Kind of.

Chances are, you probably know everything about the original FNAF if you take interest in this, so let's talk about the new animatronics.  We have the new Bonnie with his more innocent makeover, who I find scary until Night 3, when he becomes completely tame compared to everything else that is going on. Easily, the least likely to fly in your face.

The new Chika is basically a slightly better version of Bonnie, and likes to appear in the hallway with a birthday present and a stripper outfit. I wish I could make that up. Then we have the balloon boy who starts in cam 10, then flies off the face of the earth, only to randomly appear in the left vent. I have absolutely no idea where he goes.  But think of him as Nelson from the Simpsons; he's coming for you, with the intent to point and laugh at your failure until you inevitably die. But never actually attack you.

I'll save the rest for you to find out, because finding out is half the adventure. A painful adventure, where you will spend an hour figuring out how to deal  with each enemy.

The feature with this game that everyone was staining their pants with bleach over, is having no doors to protect you when Chika stands outside the window, gasping at how erect your nipples are. Or at least, that's how I pictured it. She's gotta have that shocked expression for a reason. But who needs a powerful door, when you have the most amazing flashlight, mankind has evar created?

If you have a friend who is dying from some incurable disease, flick the flashlight at them a few times and they will be skydivng into your mother's bed while holding the olympic torch. At least 4 of the animatronics will come for you from the hallway, to which you can respond by flicking at them for a minute, and they will probably be gone. Which results in the first hour of every night, being a game of red light green light with Foxy. He just loves to join the party early.

Which brings me to my next point about this flashlight. You will not run out of power. Like evar. One of the most intense parts of the original, was trying to find every animatronic who was trying to kill you, while saving power so you don't have to listen to a small classical piece, then get given a hug from Freddy for the 765th time. Use the camera and flashlight all you want, this time. You have 4 bars of battery life, and they really take their time in going away.

And if that doesn't work, then you have the Freddy disguise which really makes me question how Bonnie reacts when he sees a human and then suddenly sees his boss. If anyone comes through the vent, wea the mask and you'll be fine. At least for the most part, but I'll get into that dumb mechanic in a moment.

And lastly, we have the music box, which you can just tell was put there just to give the player a reason to check the camera. So with all of these pieces of equipment to use for so many enemies, you're always put on edge with not a moment to rest. Sounds like a formula for a scary game, to me.

And it sure is. Most of the people who play this will be sweating like a teenager who is playing pin the tail on the donkey, with the number 1 female student from yoga class. Never a dull moment.

Or at least, that's how it starts off. Point being, this game is hard. And when I say hard, I mean the hard that starts off as frustrating, before quickly downgrading to an expected annoyance. You will die in this game. A lot. Which gives you plenty of time to learn how the mechanics of each animatronic work, and by the time you do, the game becomes as scary as a mansion with a swimming pool made out of jelly. By the time I got to night 4, I knew when every jumpscare was gonna happen, so I just laid back and stared at the screen, waiting for death.

But Hedgy
date: if you understand how everything works
recommended: then it can't possibly be hard." Well you'd be right if it wasn't for 3 walking
hoursPlayed:
scrawking problems.

Old Chika.

And Old Freddy

Chances are

reviewText:
Wow. This game is amazing! I played, and I could not believe how cool it was! There are three things EXTREMELY good about it for me and something I wish...

1. The new animatronics: They look so cool! And they each have a new feature, and a new way to kill you. I also LOVE it when Bonnie slides in the room. He looks just so cute! Like a sicopathic robot, but in the form of a puppy.
2. The Design: I have to say, this new building and overall layout makes it INCREADIBLY tough to watch everything. The no doors feature caused Ballon Boy and Foxy to team up on me, but that was an awesome team up.
3. How fluently it runs: This game works better then most other games I have on Steam! So, big plus there. And the price, not too much, not not too low.

What I wish is for someone to make a Freddy Cruger Mod to replace Fazbear. Replace Bonnie with another horror movie killer and The Puppet with Jigsaw, and you're all set!

Overall, I definately recomend this game. And, seeing as this just came out now and is a VAST improvement over the first, then that make this, all the better!

Ready for Freddy?

reviewText:
The Epic Sequel to the popular First Person Shooter Four Nights at Freds. In this game, play as Larry Daley, a security guard at the popular Pizzeria, Starbucks. Your goal, just like the last game, is to stop minorities from stealing the Pumpkin Spice formula. Unfortunately, your budget has been cut AGAIN, and you no longer get Military Grade weapons. Instead, you have to fight them off with your fists. This makes the game much more challenging, as you have to get up close and personal. The only problem is, that every now and then, you have to deal with Kermit the Frog. Kermit will come out every time you forget to turn on the Singing Fish on the wall. Other than Kermit, 5 other minorities have been added to the game as well. There is Better b4nny, or Dyrus as people call him. There is also Captain Falcon, Call of Duty Ghost, Bubble Buddy, Batman, and of course, as hinted in the previews, Hatsune Miku. Now, with 11 minorities to worry about, no guns, and Kermit bugging you every time you take a ♥♥♥♥, you must survive through the night by wearing your fursona suit. If you die, you also get to play classic arcade games, like Sonic '06, Superman 64, Super Smash Bros. 4, and Sonic Boom (because Sega paid a lot of money for this game).

But don't think I didn't forget about the multiplayer! During the game, you will find various Pokemon within the tall grass, which you can capture and collect. Then, you can battle with friends over the Nintendo Wifi Network. They re-added all the original guns from the first game for these Pokemon Battles, and they added new guns, such as the Halo Pistol, and the Gravity Gun. This is the best multiplayer since Call of Duty: Modern Warfare 2, and I can't wait to see where the CoD series goes next.

The creator of the game ever worked with the makers of Dead Rising to create the new Zombie mode, where you can play as Paul Blart, Larry Daley, Tony Montana, and Captain America to fight off the alien invasion of Weeaboos. This mode also contains a vast story line, but I wouldn't want to spoil it for anyone.  Tony Montana dies in the end heuheuhue xDDD ayy lmfao .

I hope everyone enjoys this game as much as I do. Its so wonderful to see the Sonic franchise blow up so much and come out with 2 games in the same year. This will put Battlefield on the run. This game has brought me countless minute of enjoyment, and I highly reccomend grabbing it.

reviewText:
After the terror that happened in the original Freddy Fazbear's Pizza restaurant, it was shut down shortly after. But now its been reopened in a new location and you take the job as the new night security.

A few things have changed now. There are no more doors to keep you safe and you are now left in the open with a corridor in front of you and crawling vents on both sides. The only things you get are a flashlight to see what's coming and a Freddy mask to disguise you from the deadly robots.

You will find a lot more security cams in the new Freddy Fazbear's Pizza restaurant. Each security cam allows you to turn the viewing area light on and off to see what is hiding in the dark and to see what's coming for you.

New creepy sounds, locations and deadly robots make this sequel a lot scarier than the previous one. So get ready to jump out of your seat. :D

I uploaded some gameplay for you to check out:
http://youtu.be/bLuKUpVTdpo

reviewText: Follow your favourite furry robot friends (and a few new entries) in a new and magical adventure at the New and Improved Freddy Fazbear's Pizza. reviewText: Five Nights at Freddy's was a great and challenging game, but, Scott had to make a hard decision with Five Nights at Freddy's 2, that decision was, to make the game harder or easier, and I think we all know what he chose, which was to make the game harder. The noises in the game can scare you, but when you know what noise is which, such as the whirring noise, meaning something is in the hallway, and the metal rucuss of the vents. The Freddy Head is a nice mechaanic to replace the doors, but with the old animatronics, you have to put it down A.S.A.P, which is a tiny bit difficult. The thought of the building not running out of power, can make the player feel a bit safer, but that would inevitably mean the flashlight running out, and death by Foxy. The cutscenes where you are Freddy from the first game, is cool, to see his P.O.V, the multiple changes to them are nice. The Night 6 phone call can throw you off since the first game didnt have one, but Phone Guy explains that the place is shut down since somebody dressed in a yellow Freddy suit, A.K.A Golden Freddy, killed 5 childeren. The return of Golden Freddy was amazing. The game has added a lot to the mechanics, which makes the game scary and more fun. I, personally enjoy Five Nights at Freddy's 2, and cannot wait for the iOS release so I can play it everywhere I go

reviewText: If you are a fan of the first game, then the second will surely keep you satisfied. reviewText:
Holy heck, there was a sequel? Alrighty.

As a gift from a friend, I really wasn't ready for the amount of scares and pressure comin' my way.
The game is nice and seems to play, pretty much the same as the prequel, with a few added features I'll go over right now.

1.Joining the 4 animatronics that everyone is used to, you now have a new set of animatonics that are just as frightening.
2.Replacing the doors comes the Freddy Fazbear mask(?) that you can wear so whatever creeps its way into your office will creep its way out.
3.To keep up the tension, there is a music box that must be kept wound up, to prevent a certain animatronic from, well, killing you.
4.Remember when I said Replacing the doors"? Yeah
recommended: two vents. Said vents use the normal lights system from the first game. While the door must be checked using the flashlight.\n5.Speaking of flashlights
hoursPlayed: you get one! The flashlight can only be used with the cameras to check on things you probably couldn't see.\n\nThe visuals are the same as the first game

reviewText:
Five Nights at Freddy's 2 is an Indie Point and Click horror survival game that does what it says very well. It has a much steeper learning curb than the previous game, making it look like college compared to preschool. It also has better jumpscares! This game has gotten me more than any other with annoying jumpscares that you expect to some that scare the living daylights out of you. This game, although not seeming like it, has a geat story about vengeance and hatred. Sure the story ingame is vague, but the theories are OVERWHELMING! Sadly I have no face, but that's fine, since you have a Freddy Fazbear Head to defend yourself without doors!
Here's my opniion of the nights
Night 1! Allright, let's go! AH GOD, BONNIE! PUT ON THAT MASK! AH, FREDDYS IN MY OFFICE! PUT IT ON!

Welcome Back to Freddy Fazbear's Pizza i See you Survived...ready for Round 2~

Five Nights at Freddy's 2 Makes an Come back with both New Animatronics aswell as some Familar Faces from the Previous Game, However though the Rules have slighty Changed.

Doors?...Who Needs Doors - That's right Boys and Girls no more doors to keep you safe no more, instead you are now armed with weapon's, an Sword and an Shotgun you ask?, Nope an Flashlight and an Fazbear Head.

Power Meter in this game is your Flashlight Battery try to use it sparingly as the flashlight becomes your Greatest Ally in oncoming Nights, as for your Defence you have the Fazbear Head if you see an Animatronic get too close for comfort, just put this on and they will leave you alone, As before this game requries you to not over Use you Tools as it can have Deadly Results.

The Newest Addition to the Game is Music Box besure to keep and eye on it and make sure it never stops playing wind it up every chance you get......hmm what happens if it stops? i'll let you fiqure that out for yourselfs~

reviewText:
This is pretty late review, but since I've just translated my review for the first one, I decided to write few things here too.

Five Nights at Freddy's 2 is, sadly, the last good game of the series. It does everything right - it offers you more animatronics, instead of less, it adds new gameplay mechanics (and thus new level of difficulty) instead of changing game completely and, the most importantly, it unfolds more story with the minigames (which is unique idea on it's own) instead of making it too confusing and frustrating. I got the feeling that Scott Cawthon, after initial success of his games, which was gain mostly due to FNAF lore that started so many theories, tried to surprise us so much, that, if the Game Theory is right, it lead us to the most disappointing and lazy explanation ever.

FNAF 2 is enjoyable, challenging, cute on it's own weird way and the most importantly, still feel unique, while being a perfect continuation. I would say this is a good place to finish your FNAF adventure.

reviewText:
They ask me what could go wrong, and then they bring up death and dismemberment. Classic.
Being a huge FNaF fan, I can say that I was insanely hyped for this game. Though unlike some sequels out there, my hype did not die out after playing the game. The scenery is akin to the first game... But in some cases, the gameplay has been completely flipped around. Sure, you're still completely static in a claustrophobic office with only a fan and tablet to keep you company, but that's mostly it. You've still got Bonnie, Chica, Foxy, and ( My personal favorite ) Fredward Benson on your tail, but they've brought some friends this time. Sheesh, at points, even paper dolls and shadows are out to get you. The game itself is marvelous, and the storyline is definitely bone-chilling. Especially if you've delved deep into the story of the first game.

Oh, I almost forgot; you don't have doors this time either. Ain't that swell? NOPENOPENOPE.

reviewText:
This is a working review, I will update as I progress through the game.

Let me start off by saying I have never playing the first Five Nights at Freddy's; I skipped it thinking it was just a silly game will a few jump scares.

My brother talked me into picking up FNaF2. After playing a few nights with him I have to say this game is not only fun, but it's so nerve wracking it's scary. The jump scares from the animatronics are scary, but the tension you feel while trying to not only hide from them, but trying to hold back one of the most aggressive, is intense.

FNaF2 is a thrill ride with simple mechanics that keep you coming back to be scared again and again.

reviewText: The first game started out scary and ended up more than a little frustrating, but I recommended it because it was a unique experience that I was glad to have had. Unfortunately for me, Five Nights at Freddy's 2, feels like the exact same game with only minor differences that do little to change the experience. The jump scares seemed more predictable, and thus were not remotely scary, and the mechanics came down to once again pressing buttons and clicking the mouse in the right places as fast as possible without making a mistake.\n\nIf you loved Five Nights at Freddy's, you will probably love this game as it really is more of the same. But for me, it is one to miss.

reviewText: It's alright, I guess. If you liked the first one, you'll like the second one. Overall, I just wish there was more to the gameplay. By night three, you've seen most of what the game has to offer, and while the game offers a lot more than the first game, it does get a bit repetitive. I ain't the kind of guy to scream at every little jumpscare that happens in a game -- and you will likely get used to the jumpscares in due time -- but it does contain a rather nice atmosphere and feeling of tension, especially with the new Freddy mask, flashlight, and music box mechanic. It could be better, but hey, it's more unique than the onflux of horrible, deadpan jumpscare games that flood the horror industry in today's gaming market. Here's hoping that FNAF3 will be better.

reviewText: A solid sequel in all aspects. There is much less reliance on the luck of the RNG this time around, and a much higher focus on reflexes and time management. It is a sharp increase in actual difficulty, but for the most part chance is a decreased factor; no longer will Chica deciding to camp your door or Freddy lurking in the corner be an issue. Instead, you have to keep the music box wound up and Foxy appeased via flashing your light. There is no power limit; your flashlight has a battery but after some practice it will become a non-issue. It boils down to slipping on the mask to protect from the main mannequins, flashing your light to keep Foxy away, and checking the camera to wind up the music-box. For lore enthusiasts, there are many more hints and additions, explaining such things as the missing children and the Bite of '87. All in all, definitely worth the buy.

reviewText: You definitely can't go wrong for $8! The original game had a creepier atmosphere and required a little more strategy in the later nights than this one does, but at the same time it was also more unfair with the random door jamming nonsense. My only major gripe with FNaF2 is that you spend over half your time on the later nights just winding up the dang music box (you'll know what I mean if you've seen some gameplay footage on YouTube). My favorite addition to the gameplay is the little Atari-esque minigames you're sometimes given the option to play if you die; those minigames kinda help to flesh out the lore behind the restaurant chain and the infamous Bite of 1987". One last thing: managing power isn't nearly as troublesome as it was in the first game. In fact
date: all you have to conserve now is flashlight battery
recommended: and that has not proven to be a problem for me yet (I'm on Night 5).\n\nEDIT: This is the second time Steam has given my review the wrong "hours on record" stat. I have definitely played FNaF2 for more than 1 hour. =/"

reviewText:
Watch out, it's an actual review instead of yet another joke review for this game!

The first Five Nights at Freddy's, while overhyped, is still a pretty solid game. Barely over two months later, this sequel was released. That right there should ring some alarm bells. It certainly is rushed and shows some signs of the creator jumping on to the hype train while the series is still popular, rather than taking his time with a worthy sequel.

Two of the strongest aspects of the original game's horror were how good the atmosphere was and the spooky sound design. The latter is mostly gone in the sequel, with the former pretty much missing. The first game did a good job of making the pizzeria look frightening, while still matching with the description of a place that is joyous in the day. It doesn't seem like a whole lot of time was put into recreating that feel for the sequel, as the pizzeria is simply bright and colourful this time around, with no spookiness to the appearance of the diner. The only exception is the parts and services room, but of course kids aren't supposed to be there, so no attempt to blur the line of friendly and frightening was needed.

The sound design isn't even close to matching the quality of the first game's, however some of it shows promise. With some more time testing what does and doesn't work (read: not rushing the game out in barely over two months) the sound design could have been absolutely fantastic. For example, the animatronics Balloon Boy and Mangle have their own unique sounds, which excellently use common horror techniques. Balloon Boy has creepy childish sounds and Mangle pretty much is a ghost box, constant white noise and distorted voices, showing the fear behind chaos. Unfortunately there isn't really a whole lot more special going on in the sound department. The atmospheric sounds are sadly far inferior. They do their job of indicating something dangerous is nearby and that's it. Especially lazy is the sound indicating an animatronic passing through the main hall. It took me a while to realise the sound was indicating an animatronic was so close, since, well... I'm having a hard time figuring out how extremely repetitive alarm-type noise" ties into someone being in front of you? Somehow the loud footsteps from the first game conveyed that expression better. Additionally

reviewText:
Overview
=======
Five Night's At Freddy's 2 is a truly worthy sequel that without a doubt does justice to its amazing predecessor.
Turning up every single dial on the board with more gameplay mechanics, more animatronics and a vastly increased playing area, it certainly creates even more pressure and desperation for the player than the original game ever did.

Animatronics
==========
All 5 of the old animatronics return, with some additional wear and tear to boot: Freddy, Bonnie, Chica, Foxy and Golden Freddy. They are also joined by some upgraded and shiny new versions of the standard four animatronics- Toy Freddy, Toy Bonnie, Toy Chica and Toy Foxy (affectionately known as 'Mangle' due to the absolute state he is in). As if this fiendish lineup of 9 animatronics was not enough, 2 extra and unique animatronics enter the fray- the Balloon Boy, a seemingly harmless yet incredibly dangerous animatronic which messes with your lights, and the Marionette, an unspeakable terror that is quite simply your doom should it ever escape from the container it is kept in.

Gameplay Mechanics
===============
Freddy likes the dark and now things get even darker. You'll be forced to use the new camera lights in order to see into the darker depths of some of the rooms, but beware the battery meter. You must also keep on turning the jack in the box in order to escape the wrath of the Marionette. Even worse, there are no doors! One must use all of their cunning and alertness to survive the five nights without being completely dismembered by the animatronics. The Freddy Mask can assist with this, as it will fool some of the animatronics into thinking that you are the incredibly psychotic bear himself. Also, beware the new hallunications- will you discover the true story behind this cursed establishment? What is the true role of the Marionette?

Conclusion
========
I give this game a 9/10. It is truly almost perfect.

Pros:
A larger Freddy Fazbear's Pizza to perish in
More animatronics to get destroyed by
The unique graphics which give the game its signature feel return
More gameplay mechanics to offer a new experience
A scary experience

Cons:
Scott seemed to sacrifice a lot of development time (originally aiming for a 2015 release) in order to get this game out as a 'surprise' early release. Though it is indeed cool that we are able to play the game early, one is left wondering, could this game have been so much more if Scott stuck to the original deadline?

reviewText:
I must admit I wasn't expecting much going in, considering the first one to me was a big disappointment from what others said it was, and I myself am not much a horror fan, but frankly I haven't played enough of it to find it repeatitive. I can say how it can be, but with how unpredictable some of the animatronics can be, you'll be kept on your toes.

The point of the game, and I use that word loosely, is to survive 12 AM to 6 AM. You are given a job as a night guard for Freddy Fazbear's Pizzeria. but there's a big catch. There are animatronics in the restaurant that are out for your ♥♥♥, so it's a defense game in which you have to prevent said animatronics from killing you until 6 Am, in which even if they were on the brink of killing you, you go off free at 6 AM. Why they try to kill you is never explained, but the excuse is that they were never given a night mode, thus they go for where the people are, and that happens to be your office. I wonder if they kill people in other rooms during the day too, because again, why they try and MURDER you instead of sing a nice song to you during the night is never explained, but as the nights go on, through phone communication with an anonymous staff member, you are described horrific events that have went on within the restaurant. As well as that Puppet is his least favorite and Foxy is his favorite! <3~

The mechanics are simple but fun and make for a challenging and addictive expierence. There's a flashlight, which you should NOT USE FOR THE CAMERAS FOR THE MOST PART. They're only useful for actual cameras on nights 1 & 2, since you don't wanna waste any of your flashlight with how much a certain animatronic appears, and the only way to stop said animatronic is WITH THE FLASH LIGHT. The music box mechanic is pretty much the only reason to use the camera, which is...Disappointing. One of the 'major' game mechanics you never use and only need to use for one room, a similar problem in the first game with pirate cove. Scott Cawthon seriously needs to make a way to make all the cameras more significant other than just holding the animatronics in place for like 3 seconds..Sure, you could say this is pretty useful but I think it's just pathetic, considering this is probably at least what 25% of the game's data is put into. The other cameras. The death minigames are pretty cool..But there's no way to 'win' and some of them are just a chore, not even worthy of being called 'games' when you think about it. I digress, there are 3 places the animatronics can come from. The hallway in front of you, which you can press on your flashlight from within your office to check, as well as two vents on your left and right. How else to defend yourself given they make it into your office- WHICH THEY WILL BY THE WAY - well, you are given a Freddy Fazbear mask you can wear to fool the animatronics into thinking you're one of them!...Well, most of them. I will describe how I feel about the animatronics and their point in the game below.


Toy Freddy/Freddy Fazbear: I'm talking about the duo of bears that will do more than steal your precious pick-a-nick baskets, starting at the end of the hall to warn you that they're there if you flash your light down. From what I know, unlike Old Bonnie and Old Chica, these two cannot just flash in your office. Although it may be seen as 'easy to avoid' when they have stages of lurking before they actually try to attack you, it seems they catch you at the WORST time, maybe you haven't flashed the flashlight at Foxy, maybe you spent a little to much time waiting to wind up the music box, either way, it'll be these bears' fault.  Essentially, these two are saboteurs that can also kill you if given the chance.

Old Bonnie: This thing is freaking huge for some reason. Seriously, I ♥♥♥♥ my pants just from looking at how big he was the first time he appeared in the office. I don't even know why he's so big, or why specifically the front of his face is missing, but it makes for a frightening and formiddable foe. Similar to how he was in the first game, he appears in front of whenever he wants it seems. Just pop on the mask and if he catches you at the wrong time, similar to almost all of the animatronics, you'll be from loving them to hating them in a few deaths.

New Bonnie: Why the hell did this guy get so much significance, or like it seems to be the case. He has a special sequence from whenever you avoid him from killing you, he's always the first one to leave to stage, and he has a freaking guitar. Not to mention he's the only one with a full redesign for the second game. I don't know. Maybe I'm just not seeing how special he is, but maybe they should've made Freddy more special?

Old Chica: God this is probably the most unnecessarily complicated designs I've seen in a while, and sure, Scott captured the 'ruined and terrifying' thing perfect but...Something about is just..Too much. Maybe it's the double jaw making it look like it was from Twisted Metal, maybe it's the wires for hands, I don't know. She's just like Bonnie in terms of her behaivor, but unlike Bonnie she seems to never show up in the hallway, making when she appears even more terrifying.

New Chica: What the ♥♥♥♥ing hell. Wh-Why. Why does she look like she would work at Hooters if given the chance. I REALLY dislike the design, and something tells me it was partially fan/r34 inspired.  She acts just like Toy Bonnie except appears in the left vent with no special sequence, but something about HER design- everything about her design is just...Off for a kid's restaurant or at least compared to the others.

Foxy: This thing will be the bane of your existance and will probably kill you the most. He appears at the end of the hall and if you don't flash the flashlight at him, he kills you on the spot. I don't have the exact intervals in which you have to flash the flashlight, but I'm gonna say roughly 8 seconds. This is why all the other animatronics' appearances are sabotage, even if they don't get you. You're always stressed out by his presence, and to put insult to injury, his jumpscare is probably one of the scariest, given how he literally jumps at you.

Mangle: I really ♥♥♥♥ing like this things' design. I don't know why, but those huge creepy crawly things in games I really liked look-wise at least. Anyway, this is probably the most active animatronic in the game, having the ability to appear in your office at 12 AM, thus having the ability to end your game AS IT STARTS. Although it is one of the easier one's to deal with, seeing as it only appears in the right vent and can easily be avoided by you plopping your mask on.

BB (Satan): This thing is Five Night's At Freddy's Teemo (League of Legends) or Pyro (Team Fortress 2) essentially. Everybody hates him. Why? Well, if you let him into your office (Avoided by putting on your Freddy mask for a few seconds whilst he's in the left vent) he disables your flashlight, leading Foxy to brutally murder you. And he appears all the ♥♥♥♥ing time.

Puppet, The Marionette, The Puppo: This thing is the music box. The thing that always leads you to die. And neatless to mention the highly proclaimed scariest robot. But, the easiest to avoid. Just wind up that music box, and you'll keep that hipster satisfied. He gets ♥♥♥♥♥♥ if you take away his music.

Golden Freddy: T-This thing is real now. I don't know his pattern essentially, since sorry to say, I haven't beaten Night 6. BUT I HAVE BEATEN NIGHT OF MISFITS, SO CALM DOWN. His jumpscare is pretty hilarious though, it's like the Batman scene switch thing, having his face just charge towards you, dettached from his body. Nothing really else to say about it.

In conclusion, I reccomend this game for anybody who can handle the spooks. Thank for readings.

P.S. The only camera you need to check is the one with the puppet.

reviewText:
About The Game:
Five Nights at Freddy's 2 is a Twitch/Thriller adventure pretty much what you get in the first game you double and increase the difficulty and force the player to face their worst fears from the first game, in Five Nights at Freddy's 2, you're brought right up close and personal with the things you're so afraid of in the first game.

Unlike in Five Nights at Freddy's, the pizzaria has been re-opened and is now child friendly" and here is where you chose to work
date: in a safe & family friendly environment right?
recommended:
ahaha yeah think again. The game spans out exactly the same as the first it's a very simple and very easily playable & basic designed game the mechanics have been slightly changed and tweeked and new enemies have been brought to the table with different behaviours.

What you believed to be really simple & safe work turns into one of the most horrific & difficult but 100% worth it times of your life.

The Story:
The story is really simple & i basically explained it above
hoursPlayed:
you're a job seeker who found an ad in the paper about a really easy job being a security guard at Freddy's Fazbears Pizzaria doing the late shift of a night that's a Monday - Friday job with minimal pay (YAY).

The Gameplay:
You're to spend 6 hours a night in your little office doing the night shift at Freddy's Fun Farm as a Security Guard
voteText: the premise of the game is very simple
helpfulPercent:
make sure that nobody intrudes into Freddy's during the night while trying to avoid the strange & earily creepy Freddy & his robotic friends as they roam the building during the night.

Not everything is as peachy and friendly of a night time though as you'll soon find out because you're running on a timer during the night as power is scarce & you need to save the power as much as you can so that you can keep an eye on Freddy & his friends as they happen to be quite afraid of new people & tend to... well kill people who aren't familiar to them.

Each night becomes increasingly difficult & not only that but it seems to take longer to complete each night
votesHelpful: of course if that's not bad enough then you'll find comfort in the fact that Freddy & his friends become more and more active through the week & require a lot more thorough checking in order to avoid winding up like so many other Secutiry Guards before you.\n\nThis game really relies on you to be 100% alert at all times & not only is hard to do that because you're constantly switching between camera's & checking outside your office doors but Freddy & his friends tend to just randomly screw with you on certain playthroughs by disabling the power of the lights or by disconnecting your cameras
votesTotal: not only do they do that but sometimes they completely obscure the camera vision with their evil smiles or to make things worse sneak into your office & while you're busy watching the camera's feel the need to scare the living ♥♥♥♥ out of you!\n\nEnemies in Five Nights at Freddy's 2 don't always follow the same set path either
votesFunny:
enemies will often pop up in different corridors and come from differen't angles as to always keep you alert.

The Verdict:
There are SOOO many good things i can say about this game but i don't have enough characters to type all of these things
commentsCount:
and very few faults i can pick at with this game.

Although this game is designed solid & it's scares are not those small little "Oh i saw that coming but it still scared me" scares they're truly terrifying when they happen because you never really know when you're going to get caught by Freddy or his friends & whenever you do it's generally off guard they catch you.

The AI in this game although very simple is Flawless an it always manages to be challenging even if it's so simple & due to the randomization of the gameplay you never experience the same thing over and over.

Sometimes the game can feel unfair when you're almost finished and the robots all gather around you in your office
column16: or when Freddy & his friends turn off the power to the lights and leave you in the dark but it never feels 100% cheap it is just the game really screwing with you and tormenting you
column17: wanting you to continue but at the same time showing that you'll never be guarenteed a win even if you're so close.\n\nThe setting in this game although simple is designed perfect to be creepy even if it is a few different static backgrounds quickly slapped together
column18:
it's a flawless attempt at making a horror experience and it works 100% without a doubt.

I give this game a 9/10.

And i give it this because there's really no flaws in it
column19: it's just designed perfect in every way
column20:
The game is meant to be difficult & it achieves that by occasionally putting you in situations of intense thrills & other times you breeze through without even seeing Freddy or his friends

Even though the game is very much the same each time it makes the experience different each playthough so it gives it replay value & then there's the thrill of beating the levels and knowing that you've overcome the odds and made it through to the next day!

Do I Recommend This Game?:
Yes i do recommend this and i suggest that people buy this game because it's so damn cheap and a well worthy experience.

If you're on the fence about it try playing Five Nights at Freddy's 1 and see if you enjoy it as they're almost the same except with new and improved enemies & a few more hard challenges.

Five Nights at Freddy's 1:
http://store.steampowered.com/app/319510/"

reviewText: The psycopath animatronics are shutting down! Freddy Fazbear's pizza got upgraded! Freddy, Bonnie, and Chica are still alive! They are broken down but they are still active. New animatronics like Mangle, Toy Freddy, Toy Bonnie, Toy Chica, The Puppet Master, and Balloon Boy are making the old animatronics mad! They want revenge! But they still work together. Bonnie doesn't have a face! Freddy has a funny jumpscare! Chica broke her jaw! And Foxy has a screw in his head! The Puppet Master is the master of frights so watch out for his creepy tricks!

reviewText: the game is still just pictures with 3D models along with some very simple game mechanics. But, the games core is the lore and fear factor. Which has been brought up a notch in comparision to fnaf 1. There are also a total of 6 new animatronics, really upscaling the dificulty factor, possibly too much. But, regardless. The game is enjoyable and entertaining. The only bugs I can find are few but not making the game unplaying. The freddy head" seems abit overpowering at first. But on night 2 you realise that the head will not save you from all of them. the removal of the generator power bar and replacing it with a flashlight power bar makes alot more sense. Plus
date: it give you the player more focuse on the animatronics rather than your power bar. Each animatronic seems unique and has there own personality. Like the new Bonnie for example like to play guitar from time to time and loves to take "selfies" with the camera and etc. The removal of doors seems to have made the game harder. But in reality it doesn't. It really just makes the game more immersive. The thing that makes the game harder is all the new animatronics and all the new rooms. In the end
recommended: this is a great improvement from fnaf 1 but isn't too radical. I Recommend this\n"

reviewText: Five Night's at Freddy's, the name speaks for itself. Five Night's at Freddy's quickly come to be one of the biggest names of recent years, and diehard fans were waiting eagerly for a sequel, however Five Nights at Freddy's 2 fails to deliver. Your weapon this time around is a mask, a flashlight, and your trusty security camera. The fatal flaw is the delivery. There are 10+ animatronics to worry about this time around and between shining your flashlight through hallways and air vents and constantly, I mean CONSTANTLY, needing to pull up the camera to wind up a music box I got so stressed I forgot I was supposed to be scared. The original Five Night's at Freddy's created a good balance of suspense, player effort and jumpscares. This game leaves no room for suspense which in turn creates lousy jumpscares. The icing on the cake is the amount of random nonsense that really takes away from the game, making it feel less real. When looking at a room with the camera it's near pitch black, so you need a light to see, but shining a light takes away your flashlight battery? What are you shining your flashlight at the security camera and the camera is acting as a portal? And explain how I wind up" The Marionette's box while looking through the camera. Is it a bad game? Not neccesarily
date: but I would only give it a 4/10 and sadly can not recommend it to anyone"

This psychological horror game will make you think twice before you may think you're safe. I happy and proud to say, Five Nights at Freddy's two is one of the best horror games I have ever played

reviewText: Friday Night Lights Inside Freddy's 2 is an interesting one. I thought the original was over hyped but after playing it I came away with chills. I loved the first FNaF game and was wondering how well Scott would handle the sequel. The idea is still the same, watch the cameras and don't let Freddy and his pals get you. But theres a new challenge to this game. More animatronics, the original cast, the new versions, Ballon Boy and the Marionet (whos jumpscare I find to be hilarious more than scary, just because of his face) a flashlight, Freddy mask, three entry ways and no doors. Because the game has no doors, to make things easier you have unlimited power. The only thing that can run out of power is your handy dandy Flashlight. Also, the inclusion of a wearable Freddy Fazbear mask is a very nice idea. Because there are no doors, you're able to fool the animatronics into thinking you're Freddy. Much like with my last review, I am stuck on night 2 and can't fully rate this game, but for now it gets a 8.5/10

reviewText:
Didn't really scare me that much but much of the game is improved upon, and exploits have been taken away from the first game. I expected this game to be a clone of the first game, but it wasn't.

Pros
-Great ambience
-Smoother animations
-SO MANY ANIMATRONICS
-Old animatronic designs look great
-New animatronics look good in the enviroment
-DAFUQ IS THAT CREEPY ♥♥♥ KID???!!!!
-Overall has creepier atmoshpere
-Retains the feeling of helplessness as you can't move

Cons
-Audio cues are a bit too obvious
-Some animatronics are not explained how to stop or where to find, making it hard to stop them (ahem Night Two)
-New animatronics look good like I said before, but don't inspire fear in your heart
-Chica's model almost looks unfinished on certain cameras, but looks great in front of you, and on stage

In final, I enjoyed what little I have played of this game. Although this game improves and doesn't fall in many catageories, its above average and sitting at a 6.5/10 If it contains better altenative gameodes this game will jump up to a 7/10 still a great game.

-Yapper

reviewText:
Very good sequel to a very good horror game
The gameplay is similar to the original,except you have no doors to close,but have a flashlight you can use in every room on the cameras.
There's a music box that you also have to keep track of,and if you don't wind it up a certain animatronic will kill you that still scares the hell out of me to this day(won't spoil what animatronic tho).
The game has a LOT of good additions to it compared to the original,not to mention the new animatronics,again some of which still scare me to this day,and in some cases scared me a crapton more than the original to the point where I was(sort of)near tears/fearing for my life(which most other horror games have rarely been able to do when I played them)

If you're looking for jumpscare-y games that are fun and at the same time have a really interesting/creepy story when you look into it,this game is for you,and you don't have to play the original to enjoy this game since this game is really a prequel to FNAF 1

10/10 from me :)
(And quick shoutouts to Scott Cawthon for making this game and FNAF 1,because like I said horror games have never really managed to jumpscare me like this and FNAF 1 have)

reviewText: The first game was an excellent horror game, perfectly giving a feeling of stress, dread, and fright to many who played it. However, after a while it became to predictable and therefore not as scary, making it less enjoyable to play. The only thing that could revive my interest in the game was a sequel. And that is exactly what Five Nights at Freddy's did. Not only did it up the difficulty by doubling the number of animatronics, but it also made the patterns more erratic and less predictable, giving the game longevity. It brought over and intensifed the same feelings that FNaF had given to the player so it is a better scare in general. However, there is another thing that FNaF2 did that FNaF did not: Add depth. In the first game it was simply sit in a Chuck-e-Cheeses and try not to die, but in this game the between nights cinematics, the minigames, the  puppet, and even the phone calls added a layer of story and eerieness absent from the original. It leaves the gamer with questions about the story, and even throws in hints suggesting things that seem impossible (like the puppet being the ringleader of the first game). The last phone calls in the game are especially eerie and that last phone call even has a plot twist which answers questions then raises many others. This mystery floating around the game makes it much more enjoyable to play, making it not only a good scare, but a great game as well.

reviewText:
Less of a horror game, more of a strategy game.

You sit alone in a control room, while various animatronics approach and try to attack you.  They all have their own discernible approach patterns, and countering them is just a matter of resource management (your flashlight battery and a music box), and prioritizing which enemies are closest to attacking you.  If you mess up, there's a loud noise and a brief attack animation.

You have access to a camera monitor with feeds running throughout the facility, but there's never a reason to look at any feeds other than the prize room, which is where you have to go to wind the music box.  Each night lasts only a few minutes, so there's not really any time to build tension or suspense.  The animatronics don't actually move either (apart from the attack animations) - they just teleport from location to location, appearing in pre-set poses.

The game's atmosphere is creepy for about 10-15 minutes before the pattern of the game becomes tedious and boring.  The game is irritating and not scary at all.

Edit/Update: If you're wondering what kind of people enjoy this game, check out the comments on this review.

reviewText: Anyone who is still sceptical about getting this game, please read my review. FNAF 2 is probably the best one out of the 2 games. Some of the questions that people have before getting the game is how do you run out of power now? In FNAF 2, the building no longer runs out of power. So you are able to use the cameras and air vent lights as much as you want. But the thing that DOES run out of power is your flashlight. You are able to use your flashlight to check down the hallway in front of you or by using it while in the cameras to light up whichever room you are looking in. The flashlight is the most important part of the game because of the fact that it helps rid of unwanted animatronics coming down the hall and also shows where the characters are in the rooms since most of the rooms are pretty much black. Moving on. This game is very addicting and easily deserves a 10/10. The main hardest thing about the game is how active the animatronics are right off the bat and the fact that you have to keep a music box winded up. On night 1, Toy Bonnie and Toy Chica come out and are very aggresive right from the start which makes the game very hard straight from the beginning. Many times Toy Freddy will also come out on the 1st night making you have to deal with 3 animatronics right from the start. Also, there is a Marionette. This doll" hides in a present on Cam 11. This is also where there is a music box you have to wind up almost every couple seconds. By winding up the box
date: it will keep the Marionette from coming out of hiding and killing you. All together
recommended: it is a very tough game having to deal with 11 animatronics
hoursPlayed: yes you heard me 11. The old gang from FNAF 1 is back and ready to kill :). There is also the Marionette and YES THERE IS GOLDEN FREDDY. Sorry if I am not exactly correct on the amount of animatronics but either way there are a lot. There is also Balloon Boy which is another animatronic you will have to find out about yourself :). In conclusion
voteText: FNAF 2 is an amazing and very unique game. I recommend it 10/10 and advise you to buy it! Have fun playing guys! I know I did!"

reviewText: Pretty good sequel to the excellent Five Night's at Freddy's. Although still true to its genre, the game tasks you with too much to do on one night. For instance, you have to check the hallway in front of you, both vents on the sides of the room, your cameras and make sure to wind up the music box all while trying not to get killed by one of the ten animotronics roaming around the buildng. The game is also too challenging. It is very difficult to be able to put your mask down over your face when an animotronic pops up, forcing your camera down. You have to react in a split second or you die.\nOverall, Five Night's at Freddy's 2 is a good sequel, but a bit rushed, with too many things to do and how difficult it is.\nI'm going to give FNAF 2 a 6.5/10

For instance, you have to check the hallway in front of you, both vents on the sides of the room, your cameras and make sure to wind up the music box all while trying not to get killed by one of the ten animotronics roaming around the buildng. The game is also too challenging. It is very difficult to be able to put your mask down over your face when an animotronic pops up, forcing your camera down. You have to react in a split second or you die.\nOverall, Five Night's at Freddy's 2 is a good sequel, but a bit rushed, with too many things to do and how difficult it is.\nI'm going to give FNAF 2 a 6.5/10

reviewText: Whew time to take a look over the 2nd installment of this amazing franchise! Five Nights at Freddy's 2 is an amazing sequeal to FNaF 1, there is alot of cool easter eggs and characters/animatronics in this game. It's way more challenging than the first FNaF, espeacially the 20/10 mode on this game (IT'S INSANLEY HARD!!) The game also reveals more of the story to the FNaF series, leaving more questions behind. The jumpscares in here are not that scary in my opinion, there a little unexpected and scary through the first two nights, but after that it kinda repeats itself. All in all, FNaF 2 was a pretty good game, not my favorite FNaF game, but really fun to play! The mechanics are really creative and love every bit about them!! Well thats about it, hopefully you enjoyed reading this review!

reviewText:
Monmonstar’s Review of Five Nights at Freddy’s 2

!!! MINOR GAMEPLAY SPOILERS!!!

A fantastically amazing sequel to the first game which scared the ♥♥♥♥ outta me! 12 animatronics each with their own AI and ways to get rid of them (and not be killed by them). FNaF 2 is hard and when I say hard I mean hard! I feel like I'm Vishnu! Having many pairs of arms and having to do SO MANY THINGS AT ONCE!!!

However it is scary but not as tense as the last one, the problem is with FNaF 2 is that the animatronics constantly come at you, rather than a build up to the actual scare in the original, at first the jumpscares can be extremely predictable and after a while the jumpscares are just plain annoying rather than scary!

New Mechanics...

THE FREDDY HEAD

You have to do a lot to stay alive in FNaF 2, you have a new Freddy helmet mechanic where when an animatronic enters the room you have to hide being it in order to 'trick' the animatronics so it simply replaces the doors. But this is flawed in a way. While the head does provide some immersion and you can’t use the cameras or the new flashlight (I will get to that later) when the withered animatronics enter the room (The ones seen in the trailer) it’s extremely unfair towards the player, if you are 0.000000001 milliseconds early in taking the head off they will kill you without a chance and a frustrating robotic scream and one huge gaping mouth in your face to see you off to your static-screen doom!

THE FLASHLIGHT AND THE HALLWAY

This was one of the mechanics I liked the ability to light a black abyss (One huge dark hallway) in front of you to illuminate the hidden animatronics chillin' in the hallway. Foxy plays a huge role in the flashlight mechanic where as if you don’t flash your light at him from time to time" he will jump in your face! However you don’t need to worry too much as he goes away after a while (and comes back every now and then). To replace the power usage from the original game you have flashlight battery
date: you are given 4 bars (5 counting the outline) using the flashlight too much will drain power from it
recommended:
drain all of your power (or a certain little ♥♥♥♥♥ of an animatronic getting into your office!) then foxy or Freddy can get you!

Summary...

FNaF 2 is harder than the first but less scary I found
hoursPlayed:
don’t get me wrong this is break your chair scary! But the original had a more eerie ambience and scarier events (I'm never going to forget the first time I saw an "ITS ME" hallucination or all the animatronics’ parts staring at me in the repair room!)

YouTube Playlist Here of all of my playthroughs!
https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLGJwwW3BiEw80AxE56OCZVMxNgjPK9jiR"

reviewText: This is one of the more scarier games, but the thing is that after hours of the same old jumpscares, it starts to get boring ,and it turns from a heart racing game, to a game that you just play through. When I played the first game for the first time,   I could only stand playing 1 night at a time, then I finished that game. But when 2 came out I just had to buy it. I played it and I still could barely play it. When I got to night four, I failed  ALOT. After Playing night 4 for about 40 minutes, it didn't really seem scary anymore. Foxy was always in your hallway, toy bonnie was always in your vent. Mangle was always near you, and cheeca showed up a lot too. Even though you can get used to this game's scariness, I still play it because of how deep the story goes. Even though I'm sure there are millions of theories, I dont really believe them. The reason for theat is that Scott Cawthon left sooooo many questions un-answered, so many easter eggs, it kept people playing. And that is why I loooove this game so much because of all of the secrets within. I definitly recomend playing either the first or second game. They both have so many un-answered questions, keeping the minds of people thinking.

reviewText: I didn't really expect much except a reskin of FNAF, especially considering how quickly this sequel has been released after the first game. Very wrong. It's from the same recipe book, but it's a very different gumbo of terror. There's much more to do and juggle around, and the rather naked feeling of having no doors this time really adds to the fear factor. No draining power this time, except for your flashlight which you can use in your office and on the camera feed (somehow - we're not bothered about how that works). The 30's cartoon-eque new gang are quite disturbing and there are some other new friends I didn't expect at all. It feels very polished and tightly coded, no 'rushed' feel to it as I was fearing. Scott really has a great understanding of how to make simple things scary. If you were a fan of the first game, you'll love this one even more.

reviewText:
This is a sequel to the ever famous Five Nights at Freddy's. There are no doors, you only get a Freddy Fazbear mask to keep the animatronics away. You also have a flashlight with limited power. I give this game a solid 10/10.

reviewText: Five Night's at Freddy's 2, the sequel to FNAF... or is it? Once again you are the security gaurd at the new and improved Freddy Fazbear's Pizza, surviving the night from the animatronics, and barely getting enough money to buy something useful. This time you only have a secuirty camera, a flashlight, and a freddy fazbear mask to fool most of the animatronics, as well as winding up a music box to keep one animatronic at bay. Now unlike the first game which only had 4 Animatronics (5 if you count Golden Freddy) This one has 10 (11 if counting Golden Freddy) so even with the freddy head and flashlight the game is much harder than the first game. I mostly recomend this for hard core gamers.

reviewText: This is a great sequel! ten out of ten for awesomness! ten out of ten for suspense! and ten out of ten for story! My main/only  problem with this game is that it is the turning point where fnaf started feeling milked and the community became too fervent and cancerous. Another point why it is the best in the series is that it has the most replayability with a large set of unique challenges presented for night 7 and a variety of collectible plu shies that you just have to get on your desk.
